content: Fill out the Agenda and tik about whether you would like to add an a remote team activity (e.g., icebreaker) to start with!

The Event Storming facilitator's main responsibility is to create safe environment for the exchange and output of ideas and data. For groups of 15-20, usually count 2 to 3 facilitators.


Start simple and then add the information in layers, incrementally.


Event Storming is usually conducted in two phases. A high level Event Storm to identify the domains and then a subsequent Event Storm into a top constraint - the core domain.

Business stakeholders, Business Analysts, Executives, Developers, Architects, Team Leads, Domain Experts,

Core Team members.

What is this method?

Drive out the the domains, bounded contexts & services of a system to reveal vertical slices, trouble spots & starting points for rearchitecting it.

Event Storming enables decomposing monoliths into microservices. It allows for modeling new flows and ideas, synthesizing knowledge, and facilitating active group participation without conflict in order to ideate the next generation of a software system.

Please remain on mute when not speaking


Please turn video on


Please announce if you are leaving/arriving during the sessions


Use Zoom’s chat feature to request to speak or ask a question if needed


Please refrain from side conversations as they distract people

When you need to:

  • clarify a current state via cross-functional communication
  • break down monolithic systems
  • identify the top constraint in a system
  • identify subdomains and bounded contexts of a system

Customize these boards as needed; it will not affect the master template.


Copy and paste additional frames for individuals/teams.


Be sure to include navigation waypoints to help people navigate when zooming in and out.


Lock frames and anything you don't want to get accidentally moved (i.e., everything except Sticky Notes?).


Remove all facilitator notes (this box, the Facilitator Notes & Tips box, Facilitator Tips and Tool Tips) before running the activity; all facilitator elements are grouped. Click on this box and delete.


Copy and paste Sticky Notes to sort them in the 2x2s instead of dragging them over; this ensures you don't lose anything.


Practice ahead of time.


Make use of the "Bring everyone to me" feature if people are struggling to navigate the Miro board. Click your initials in the top right corner.


Have a a facilitator-only messaging channel for back-channel communication.


Open the Frames menu to easily navigate between sections while facilitating, which helps avoid too much movement on screen when moving between sections.

Ensure that there is equal representation of different disciplines present.


Try to time box explanations in order to keep things succinct.


Create a space in which people feel comfortable being honest by setting up the right context for the session.


Curtail finger-pointing or unkind feedback.


Ensure that the actions are actionable and not too general (e.g., "Don't do this ...").

We set clear goals and will stick to today’s timed agenda


We will improvise the agenda if necessary


We stay focused and put digressions in the “Parking Lot” for conversations getting in-the-weeds


We encourage balanced speaking time to increase alignment and understanding

You know you’ve finished when you have:

  • Shared understanding of the system / business process
  • Ubiquitous Language for clear communication across groups
  • A list of Service Candidates to begin rearchitecting the system
  • A list of user journeys or system functionality, also known as "thin slices" that can be used when exercising the system model (see Boris)
  • Top pains/constraints in the system
  • A system/vision oriented thought process
Take some time at the beginning of the workshop to outline expected outcomes with a dashed box.
If you have a large group, consider breaking into teams for generating ideas.

Sometimes referred to as "domain event", a Business Event is something that happens in the business process.


Examples: "application completed", "validation failed", "food consumed"


Add a yellow post it for every business event that you can think of.


  • Don't worry about duplicates, we'll go through that later.

  • Write each event in the past tense, one per post it.

Pick post-its one-by-one and order them on the board:


  1. Identify the beginning and end of the event storming session,

  for example:


  1. START: customer went to website
  2. END: customer received food delivery


  1. Place the business events on the boards in time order

  from left to right, and deduplicate them


  1. Represent parallel processing using vertical space


  1. When there is confusion or conflicts around language, agree on common language and add a sticky to the "Definition"


  1. Tag post-its with "unclear" in red when there are questions

  or a need for clarification
